Dialogue.Line: Bombay Tokyo shipment activated. Bombay sending now. Tokyo receiving now. Dispatch completed. New York to Moscow delayed. Moonbase clearance awaited. Stockholm Washington personnel transportation. Stockholm sending now. Washington receiving now. Dispatch completed. Non-arrival shipment of synthetic protein New York to Moscow. Moonbase clearance awaited.
Brent?
Yes, Miss Kelly?
Why is there a delay at Moon Control?
There's some mix up with the Moscow shipment. It seems to have landed up in Canberra.
Fewsham again, I suppose? Take Moscow out of phase while they sort it out.
Moscow pending. Moonbase clear.
Toronto Calcutta shipment activated. Toronto sending now. Calcutta receiving now. Dispatch completed.
Moscow ready now, Miss Kelly.
Report Canberra Moscow situation, please.
Canberra Moscow clear.
Brent, tell them to activate.
Canberra Moscow, go ahead please.
Canberra sending now. Moscow receiving now. Dispatch completed.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man beams into a teleport cubicle and there is a chime. He strides across the floor swinging his briefcase.

Dialogue.Line: Good morning, Gia.
Morning. Just as well you've arrived.
Why, what's up?
The sooner you take over from Fewsham on Moon Control, the better.
Oh, not again!
All T-Mat consignments are five minutes behind schedule.
What?
Fewsham routed a large Moscow consignment through to Canberra.
Oh, he's a lunatic.
You should never have recommended him for an Assistant Controller's job in the first place.
Yes, I know now, but I thought he deserved a break.
Sentimental. He'll do something really disastrous one day and you'll have to answer for it.
So, I'll go and work in a synthetics factory.
It's your career.
So it is. Hey, have you got a T-Mat cubicle ready for me?
Yes. Number six.
See you later.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood steps into another cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Prepare lunar cubicle number six for transport to Moon Control.
Ready and waiting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood blows Kelly a kiss.

Dialogue.Line: Activate.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood vanishes.

Dialogue.Line: It's lucky he got here before your man arrived.
Yes, he's late. Keep a public T-Mat cubicle open for him.
Right. Local cubicle two holding open.
Report Moonbase situation please.
Moonbase clear. Routine shipments transferring on automatic control. Local arrival cubicle two activating.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A silver-haired man steps out.

Dialogue.Line: Morning, Brent.
Morning, sir.
Good morning, Gia. All functioning well?
Of course, Commander Radnor.
In your case, Miss Kelly, efficiency and charm go hand in hand.
I try to keep things running smoothly.
Nothing ever goes wrong while you're on duty.
I don't allow it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Radnor goes into his office.

Dialogue.Line: You may have been on duty all night, Fewsham, but that's no excuse for this kind of slip-up!
They weren't a major hold ups, just a few minutes.
Kelly was going mad back on Earth Control.
She would.
Look, I'm sorry, Fewsham, but it's my head in the noose as well, you know.
I know, I'm sorry.
Oh, all right. All right, go on. You'd better get back to Earth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham goes to a cubicle, but an alarm sounds.

Dialogue.Line: Now what?
The outer door airlocks.
Who's there?
No one.
Then how come the airlocks are in use?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A man screams just outside the control room. Osgood and Fewsham open the doors and he falls into their arms.

Dialogue.Line: Phipps! What is it, man? What's happened? Come on, man!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another scream and two more men run in.

Dialogue.Line: Close the doors, we've got to keep

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But what is in the corridor makes them freeze in fear.

Dialogue.Line: Don't move, anybody. Don't do anything. Harvey, don't!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The light of a weapon kills Harvey.
The Delay light is blinking.

Dialogue.Line: Not again.
The second Moscow consignment?
Yes. They'll think we're deliberately sabotaging their stuff if this goes on.
T-Mat reception, Earth to Moon. Controller Kelly calling. Switch your communication links to video.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The video screen is blank.

Dialogue.Line: Osgood's gone too far this time. There'll be trouble.
No! I refuse!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The unseen visitor speaks with a harsh, hissing voice.

Dialogue.Line: You would be wise to co-operate at once, otherwise you will be destroyed.
Well I, I suppose that leaves me no alternative.
Don't do it, sir.
Silence.
There's a certain element of risk.
You are wasting time.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood operates some switches under the video screen. Smoke starts pouring out of the sides.

Dialogue.Line: What is happening?
I'm afraid there has been a fault. The circuit's overloaded. Very unfortunate.
You have deliberately sabotaged this apparatus. Kill him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Osgood turns and gets shot with the alien weapon.

Dialogue.Line: I thought the system was infallible?
It won't be anything serious.
I'm glad you think so.
Brent, is there any obvious damage?
No damage reported. All links stable.
That's only local, surely.
It's only one stage of the checking process. Report on Intercity T-Mat breakdown.
Complete power phase blank.
State of materialisation pulse generator?
Overloaded in power surge. No damage this end.
Check with Moonbase.
Primary video link dead.
Cause?
Being investigated.
Are you sure it isn't serious?
My staff are running a thorough and immediate check. Until I have their report, I can't answer.
Then they'd better hurry. I want that report. Soon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Tardis is making materialisation sounds.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor, if we've landed, where are we?
That is what I'm trying to find out, Zoe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner picks up -

Dialogue.Line: A rocket?
Hey, we're just hanging in space.
We can't be.
Well, let's try and find a star we know.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The scanner image swings round to a CCCP space suit.

Dialogue.Line: Ah there we are. What in heavens name?
Hey, what's he up to?
He's trying to climb aboard.

Just a minute, just a minute. Oh this control is. There we are. Now that, that's an ion-jet rocket of the 21st century, but, this helmet, if I can. There we are. That's not nearly so sophisticated. It's certainly not later than 1960.
Well, those letters on his helmet?
C C C P.
Aye.
Of course!
What?
Just a minute.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor gets the scanner to turn in the opposite direction, and reveals an old document with backwards writing on it.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, I think that explains it.
Oh Doctor, what is it?
Hmm? Well it's a flying machine, designed by a gentleman by the name of Leonardo Da Vinci in about 1500.
Well, what's it doing up here?
Doctor, where are we?
Aye.
We're in a museum!
A what?
A space museum! Look, there you are.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Wright Brothers airplane, capsule with an astronaut taking a tethered space walk, Montgolfier's balloon

Dialogue.Line: A balloon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Spitfire, a HOTOL style American Airlines plane.

Dialogue.Line: That's a transport plane. And, now those initials, they stand for Russia. That's Gagarin, the first Earthman in space. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A rocket launch, TravelMat Relay over an image of the Moon.

Dialogue.Line: Come on. Let's have a look round, shall we?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe Leave the Tardis. The Doctor turns back for his jacket.

Dialogue.Line: Just a minute. Wait for me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Exhibits include the Astral map from the  Web Planet.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, quite a place, isn't it?
Oh, my word.
Hey, look at the size of this one, Doc.
Yes. My word, Jamie, look at that.
Oh Doctor, look!
Very large.
Doctor, look.

Dialogue.Character: (The rocket model they first saw on the scanner. JAMIE
Dialogue.Line: Hey, look at that.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe presses a button on a panel.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Zoe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a chime.

Dialogue.Line: What's that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A screen drops down on the wall behind them, and an information video plays.

Dialogue.Line: Travel Mat is the ultimate form of travel. Control centre of the present system is the Moon, serving receptions at all major cities on the Earth. Travel Mat provides an instantaneous means of public travel, transports raw materials and vital food supplies to all parts of the world.
Travel Mat? It sounds like a flying carpet.
Shush, Jamie, I'm trying to listen.

Travel Mat supersedes all conventional forms of transport. Using the principle of dematerialisation at the point of departure, and rematerialisation at the point of arrival in special cubicles, departure and arrival are almost instantaneous.
Faster than light.
Although the system is still in its early stages, it completely automated and foolproof against power failure.
Aye, well, we have our own system, thank you, only it isn't foolproof.
Jamie, I think that's just a tiny bit

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor turns and raises his hands in surrender to the weapon pointed at him. Jamie and Zoe do likewise.

Dialogue.Line: You saw what happened to your superior. You would do well to co- operate.
Killing him didn't do you any good.
But you will do as I ask.
There is nothing I can do!
You do not want to die?
Look, I'm not that good enough a technician. It needs an expert.
But you are second in command here.
Yes, but
Then you must have certain abilities. You must know what needs to be done.
In theory, yes.
Then you will do it.
He'll only make it worse.
What is their status here?
Maintenance. Second class technicians.
There's only one person who can really put things to rights, and she's at Earth Control.
Without her, it just can't be done.
Who is this specialist?
Miss Kelly, technical coordinator. But there's no way to reach her. T-Mat is not working.
But you have a video link.
Yes, but Osgood wrecked that too.
So, there is no means to communicate with Earth?
No, you've cut us off completely.
In that case, you are useless. You will all be destroyed.
No, there's the emergency T-Mat link! It only operates from here to Earth.
Then you will activate the apparatus. At once.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham hurries to the controls.

Dialogue.Line: It's damaged, too!
These technicians will help you repair it.
We won't help you. Neither will he.
Then he will die. You will start work at once. There will be a guard at the door. When I return you will have the T-mat link ready for operation.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Slaar, who we have not yet seen, leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Don't be such a fool, Fewsham. If we repair the emergency link these creatures can travel to Earth!
What about us?
Do you think that will make any difference in the end? As soon as he gets what he wants out of us, we'll mean nothing to him.
If we co-operate there's still a chance.
Osgood didn't take it.
You saw! Do you think I want to die like that? I want to live!
Brent, is there anything at all, any trace of a reason?
Every link has been double-checked. This end is functioning normally.
Then it must be Moonbase.
We've no way of checking their apparatus from this end, and they don't answer our call.
Where's Commander Radnor?
Not back from the Intercity Council meeting yet.
He'll expect a full report.
Well, there it is. We've even checked the computer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Brent gives Kelly a piece of paper and leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Have you located the cause of the breakdown?
This end is absolutely clear.
That isn't what I want to know.
We cannot trace the fault.
Miss Kelly! I have senior government officials hounding me. They expect a more informative answer, and so do I.
There isn't one. The trouble is at Moonbase.
Why can't you deal with it?
We can't get there.
We can't even talk to them.
Do you mean to tell me that there's no other way of contacting them?
No.
Only by rocket.
That could be our only answer.
But the only place you'll find a rocket is in a museum.
Exactly.
And even if there was one that could be made operational, there's no- one that could control such a project.
You're wrong. There is just one man, one man alone who can help us now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The weapon is held by an elderly man with a quilted body-warmer over his clothes.

Dialogue.Line: For the last time, who are you and what are you doing in my private workshop?
Now just listen, there really is no need for all these histrionics. We are perfectly harmless.
How did you even get in here?
Oh well, the usual way. We just materialised.
The T-Mat cubicle always gives automatic warnings, but it didn't this time.
Well that's not our fault, is it?
Why did you come?
Well, this is a museum.
The museum is (sees the Tardis) What on Earth's that? It's a 20th century Police Box, isn't it?
Well, yes, in a way.
Well, how did a thing like that get in my museum?
Oh, well you could say it was a form of space ship.
Zoe, I think we do owe this gentleman an apology. We really are most interested in the museum, Mister?
Eldred, Professor Eldred. Look, the museum is closed to the general public. You've obviously made a mistake. Perhaps you'd be good enough to leave.
Are you in charge of this place?
I own it. That is why I have the right to ask you to leave.
Yes, but there's no need to threaten us, you know.
Trespassers are not welcome. Will you please go!
We're not trespassers. We're very interested.
Interested? In Professor Eldred and his antiquated machines? Come for a good laugh, I suppose, like the rest of them.
Laugh? You mean people laugh at all this? Why, it's a magnificent exhibition.
We've had enough souvenir hunters, too!
Now, we're not thieves, you know.
No, of course not. We haven't come to take anything. We genuinely are interested in space travel. Why, especially a thing like this. This is superb.
Yes, magnificent. It was to have been the vehicle to take man beyond the moon. T-Mat put an end to all that.
You mean this model's been abandoned? But it's speed and stability concept alone, it's a tremendous advance in rocket design.
Exactly! Exactly! Here, let me show it to you. Let me show it to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Eldred puts down his gun and helps the Doctor with the ion jet rocket model.

Dialogue.Line: I'll give you an hand, here we are. Oh yes, this is superb. My word.
And the secret, the real breakthrough, was a compact generator of enormous power.
I see. And these must be the secondary electrode accelerators.
Yes. You see it beat the problem of the neutral caesium ions. And incidentally, it magnified the g-thrust to fantastic proportions!
That was awkward. What did you do about that?
Well, I'll show you. Come with me, I'll show you. Look.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Eldred and the Doctor go to the back of the room.

Dialogue.Line: What have we go here? Ah, blueprints!
Look at them, like a couple of kids.
Yes. You can tell he's almost in love with that rocket.
Shush!
That's not surprising. I designed it. I've been in rocketry all my life. My father engineered the first lunar passenger module, and I travelled on the last trip back to Earth. Before it all finished.
Before all what finished?
Space travel.
But if the rocket was so good, why did you stop at the moon?
Aye, why end there?
Because of T-Mat. T-Mat, the ultimate in travel. With about as much sense of adventure as a synthetic carbohydrates factory.
But surely rockets would still be useful as an auxiliary means of transport, wouldn't they? Besides, how would man get beyond the moon?
Nobody cares any more about exploring space. Life made. Well, it was made too easy by T-Mat.
I see. So you lost government backing?
The project was abandoned, except by me.
You've got to help me. If we don't repair it, we'll all be killed.
Maybe we could repair it and T-Mat back to London.
With that thing guarding the door? I'm going to keep on trying.
Maybe there is something we can do.
What?
I knew you'd see reason.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Locke goes to the panel Osgood sabotaged.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
The video link with Earth. Yes, it's not so badly damaged as the T-Mat.
We were told to repair the T-Mat link, not the video.
Let's have a look. If we can't escape ourselves, maybe we can get a message through by video.
Look, the guard will see what we're doing. He'll kill us!
You play your game, we'll play ours.
No more money, no more facilities. A life's work abandoned just like that. All because of T-Mat.
Well, I can understand your bitterness. Very short-sighted of the government to put all their eggs in one basket.
You still haven't told me who you are and what you're doing here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Beep!

Dialogue.Line: Well.
That's the main-door alarm! What's going on?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Radnor and Kelly enter.

Dialogue.Line: Professor Daniel Eldred. Well, well, well.
Radnor. Come to see how your spies are getting on?
I'm sorry? I don't think we've met. My name's Radnor. This is Miss Kelly.
Oh, how do you do. This is Zoe, and Jamie, and I'm the Doctor.
Hello.
Hello.
Oh, Radnor, don't pretend that you don't know them.
I can assure you I've never met them before in my life.
I see. I find three strangers prowling around my museum, and by the merest co-incidence you turn up on their very heels.
I can assure you I merely wanted a chat with a very old friend.
Why? You've done without a chat for a good many years.
Old times. Friendships don't die.
Our friendship ended the day that you walked out of my laboratory and joined the government administration on T-Mat!
Different men, different careers, Daniel.
Yes, but you happened to know which career was going to be financed by government funds.
But you could have come over with me. We asked you to join us.
Yes, and worked as Miss Kelly's assistant perhaps?
You know I respect your work, Professor Eldred. We would have welcomed you on T-Mat.
I prefer rockets, obsolete as they are.
Not so obsolete as all that, Daniel, eh?
What?
We don't miss very much, you know.
So you've been spying on me.
Oh, no, no, no, no. We stopped that a long time ago.
I should think so. What's wrong with running a private museum?
Nothing, but you're doing rather more than that, aren't you, Daniel.
All right, what if I am? It's a free country, isn't it? What's wrong with having a hobby?
Rather more than a hobby, preparing an ion rocket for an unauthorised journey into space.
All right, so you know. What do you intend to do?
My dear fellow, help you, of course.
What?
You can make your trip with full government backing, as long as it's to the moon.
Why the moon?
There's a minor fault developed at T-Mat control at Moonbase.
And we have to put it right, quickly.
I thought T-Mat was infallible.
It will be, eventually, however we have no way of reaching the moon.
Except by out of date rocket. Oh, that's perfect! So you need me after all.

I thought you'd be taken with the idea, Daniel. And a large sum of government funds wouldn't come amiss, would they? Now, how soon can you be ready to (pause) blast off. Well, come on, it's urgent! Can you give me an approximate ETD?
I could.
Good!
But I won't!
Why? There are no strings.
I don't have to give you reasons. I'm just telling you that I refuse.
Right, that should do it.
I'll switch on the power.
You fools. When they find out, we'll all be killed.
Moonbase to T-Mat Reception Earth. Moonbase to Earth. Emergency. Emergency.
You can't refuse, man. There's more at stake here than an out of date rocket programme.
Commander Radnor.
Excuse me. Radnor.
Emergency message from Moonbase linking through now. LOCKE [on monitor]: Commander Radnor, Miss Kelly. We are in desperate trouble. Osgood is dead and we're

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: Locke! Locke!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps runs for the door.

Dialogue.Line: Stop him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior fires too late. Phipps is off down the corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Hunt that man. He must not escape.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior leaves.

Dialogue.Line: You allowed them to send a message back to Earth.
They tricked me! I tried to stop them.
No matter. He will be found and killed.
What about me?
Have you repaired the emergency T-Mat link?
Not yet. It isn't easy.
But it is possible?
Yes, only give me time.
Very well, but now you know what will happen if you fail. You will die.
Daniel, don't you see this goes far beyond a petty quarrel over rockets and T-Mat! Those men at Moonbase are in serious trouble and we must help them.
You'll have to find some other way.
With T-Mat dead there is no other way. Your rocket is our only hope of reaching the moon.
Professor, listen to them.
I'm listening.
In a way this is a triumph for your rocket.
Is it?
Of course it is. The government recognises the fact.
Then the government is going to be disappointed.
I don't understand you.
Oh, I'd better be frank with you.
Yes, I think you'd better.
I must admit I played with the idea of making a space flight. I even prepared a rocket.
Well then?
It was just a dream, an illusion for a disappointed man.
You mean there's nothing?
Oh, the rocket's there, partially prepared.
Good!
As for an actual lift off
We can do it, Daniel. I know we can.
It takes more than enthusiasm to get a rocket off the ground.
You've only to ask for what you want. Funds, men, equipment.
It needs the one thing that you have not got. Time.
A crash programme with the best available technicians.
It's nowhere near ready, woman! Most of the equipment is still unchecked.
A computer can be programmed for that.
It would still be impossibly dangerous.
Daniel, it was you who created this rocket. It was your driving force and enthusiasm that got it off the drawing board. With you in control, we can't fail to succeed.
That was a long time past. Now my heart couldn't take the strain of the G-force.
That doesn't mean your experience and knowledge are useless. We need your guidance.
No. I told you it's a dream. I can never go to the moon and neither can rocket ZA685.
Could we not help them? We could use the Tardis.
What, for a trip to the moon?
Aye.
We'd probably overshoot by a few million years.
Yes, or by a few million miles. I'm afraid the Tardis is not suited to short-range travel.
Still, I think we should help them if we can.
Aye.
Yes. I think I could get your rocket to the moon.
You?
Yes, I have considerable experience in space travel, and so have my two companions.
Doctor, that's splendid. Thank you.
But the rocket is not ready!
Well, perhaps you're overestimating the difficulties. How much more work is required on your rocket?
It needs fuelling, and a complete computerised check-up.
Well, I can order that.
No! I will not allow it! The risk is too great. No!
If there was some other way, believe me I wouldn't even consider such a risk.
No!
There's always the outside chance that the fault in T-Mat will clear itself.
Commander Radnor. Urgent.
Excuse me.
Radnor. Go ahead.

T-Mat receptions New York, Moscow, Tokyo express great concern over continued hold-up. Medical shipments and food supplies awaiting transit to Asiatic centres. Position desperate, Calcutta. Instructions awaited.
That's your answer.
Well, we're willing to help, as I've said.
You don't know what you're doing. It's suicide.
Listen, if this fault lasts much longer, there's going to be worldwide chaos, and world population is at stake.
Infallible T-Mat putting the world in jeopardy?
All right, I admit it.
And now you want this man to risk his life to get you out of trouble.
No, not me, but thousands of people all over the world who will die if we don't take this risk. I'm sorry, but I've got no alternative. Miss Kelly?
Sir?
I want all technical personnel working on this. I want that rocket prepared for launching.
Yes, Commander.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly leaves.

Dialogue.Line: We'd be grateful for your help.
If that rocket is going to reach the moon safely, you'll need more than help. You'll need a miracle.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ice Warrior meets up with another at the junction.

Dialogue.Line: Continue the search. He must not escape.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps is hiding behind machinery in the Solar Energy Store Room. A Warrior enters, looks around, fails to see him and leaves. When the corridor is clear again, Phipps closes the door and takes a Solar Amplifier out of its box.
Everyone is writing on clipboards.

Dialogue.Line: Commander?
Yes, Miss Kelly?
Do you think it's wise letting these people crew the rocket?
Wise? No, of course it's not wise, but what's the alternative? We gave up training astronauts years ago.
But who are they?
Some of Eldred's crazy friends, I imagine. But the man who calls himself the Doctor certainly knows his space travel.
How can you be sure?
Well, you wanted the briefing, but he and the girl know more about space flight than Eldred.
What about the boy?
Yes, I'm not sure about him. Doctor?
Yes?
Tell me, are all three of you planning to crew this rocket?
Oh aye. I can be useful too, you know.
Jamie, I hadn't thought about you.
Hey, you're not leaving me behind and that's final.
There can be no excess weight on this trip.
Well, how much many this rocket thing hold?
Well it was designed for a three man crew.
Ah. Well then, I'm going.
Commander?
Yes, Miss.
The chemical fuel reserve stocks at launching site are barely adequate for a moon journey and return.
What about other sources of supply?
New York and Moscow. Transit impossible due to T-Mat malfunction.
But surely it's only a question of getting to the moon. We shall come back by T-Mat, won't we?
Possibly. Depends what's wrong with it.
There is another source of supply.
Oh, what's that?
The fuel dump on the moon. There's a refuelling system connected to the landing bay.
But surely that equipment hasn't been used for years.
Neither has the radio homing beam, and if that doesn't work you'll never make a landing at all.
Oh, in that case we needn't worry about getting back.
Well, all the equipment has been completely automated and solar powered. Designed all myself. No reason why it shouldn't work.
I'm sure it will.
Are you sure you remember all that I told you at the briefing?
Oh yes, and even if I don't, Zoe has total recall.
Well, just in case, I've written it all down here.
There's no need, we.
And there's a map of Moonbase, too. Now, you know how to operate the homing beam?
Now don't worry about a thing. Your rocket is going to be in good hands.
Ahem.
That's quite enough, Jamie.
And remember you've only got enough food and water for three days.
Yes, well we've taken (conversation carries on in background)
Commander?
Yes, Miss Kelly?
I think I should go as crew on the rocket.
Don't be ridiculous. You're too valuable here.
But how can T-Mat be repaired if I'm not there?
Well, what about the other technicians already there?
Osgood's dead.
Yes, well, what about Fewsham? Phipps?
Oh, he's incapable of repairing it. I think I should go.
No! You're the only one who really understands T-Mat. I can't have you risking your life.
And yet you're perfectly prepared to allow them to risk theirs.
Now don't worry, Miss Kelly. We're going to be perfectly all right.
But how can you be sure? You don't even know what the trouble is up there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham is still working on the control panel. Two Warriors stand guard.

Dialogue.Line: The emergency link with Earth, is it ready yet?
I've nearly finished.
Do not make any mistakes.
I am not an expert.
But you will do it.
Yes! But I don't see what good just this emergency link can be. Even if you had a gigantic army of warriors, you couldn't send them all to conquer Earth.
We do not need an army. Earth will be ours for the taking, very soon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the Solar Energy Store Room, Phipps looks around for something, then finds an infra-red lamp. He plugs it into the Solar Amplifier then hunts for the Solar Power Line. It is hidden behind some old canisters.

Dialogue.Line: Ignition reserve power.
Fully charged. KELLY [on monitor]: Internal atmosphere settings?
All normal. ELDRED [on monitor]: Trajectory bearings, orbital lock.
Pre-set registering normal functions.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A few tables and microphones in a room at the museum.

Dialogue.Line: Lift off activation check complete. All readings alpha green.
Well done. In record time and not a thing wrong.
So far.
Doctor?
Yes?
Final check on procedure after you land.
Oh yes, I know. We're to re-establish video link with the Earth.
That's right. When we can see what's wrong, you can do the rest under Miss Kelly's supervision.
Right. We're ready when you are.
Link programme to telemeter guidance. KELLY: Three minutes. Countdown will begin at T minus sixty seconds.
This is it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: ZA685 stands alone on its launch pad. No gantry, no feeder lines, nothing.

Dialogue.Line: All functions are on computer controlled pre-set. Clear launching site.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The crew capsule is suitably cramped.

Dialogue.Line: Three minutes seems an awfully long time.
Yes. You remember your take off briefing, Jamie?
Aye, he's told me all about this G-force stuff. Now I know.
You don't know about it until you've experienced it.
Look Zoe, I'll have you know that the Doctor and I have
T minus sixty seconds from now.
There's one minute to go. Now hold tight, everyone.
Well, I'm all right, Doctor. How about you, Jamie?
(scared) Look, I keep telling you, I'm fine.
T minus fifty.
Make sure telemeter guidance is operative!
Don't worry, everything's been checked and rechecked.
T minus forty. Technicians report.
All areas clear.
Check all systems.
We have.
We must make sure.
T minus thirty. Twenty six.
Twenty two. Eighteen. Fourteen. Twelve. Ten.
Ten, nine, eight, Seven, six, five, four, three, two, one. We have lift off.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Archive footage of a Saturn V heading for the stratosphere.

Dialogue.Line: I never thought I'd see that again. A rocket rising in flight.
Beautiful! Let's see how they are. The link is dead!
What? Something must have gone wrong on lift off.
Try the shadow channel.
Nothing.
Do you mean to say we're out of touch completely?
What about radio link?
Earth control to rocket. How do you read me? Over.
Nothing but static.
It's only a minor fault, surely.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Weightless but still strapped into their seats.

Dialogue.Line: Earth control to rocket. How do you read me? Earth control to rocket.
Don't release your safety straps until I switch over to automatic gravity control, otherwise you'll float away.
Earth control to rocket, how do you read me?
Oh, wait a minute! Switching to automatic gravity control now.
Try again.
Earth control to rocket.
Rocket to Earth Control. Wait a minute, can't you? We've only just recovered from take-off.
Is everything all right? We seem to have lost our video monitor link.
Yes, I think there must be a fault in one of the circuits.
Doctor? Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Smoke is coming from a panel.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
Well, one of the circuits has burnt out, Zoe. I'll switch to a secondary one.
Oh, no. This is worse than the Tardis.
Do you read me, Doctor?
Sounds as though the entire communications circuitry has blown out.
Yes, let's hope that's all that's happened.
Keep trying, Miss Kelly.
It's done. The emergency link will work now.
Excellent!
What are you going to do?
Do not ask questions. Activate the link. On receive only.
Receive? But aren't you going to send anybody
Activate the link on receive at once!
And you've double checked everything? BRENT [on monitor]: Yes. The fault is definitely at Moonbase.
Is it possible for you to effect repairs over video?
Provided the fault is not too major.
And provided they actually get there in the rocket.
They'll get there.
Why? How do you know? You can't even be sure the rocket's still in one piece. BRENT [on monitor]: Miss Kelly!
What is it, Brent? BRENT [on monitor]: We've got through. The emergency T-Mat link to Moon Control is activating.
Is someone coming through? BRENT [on monitor]: No, it's on send.
Moonbase must have managed to make a temporary repair.
It seems odd.
That's all we need. Brent, have a full emergency kit waiting. I'll join you as soon as possible. BRENT [on monitor]: Yes, Miss Kelly. Crew are standing by.
Where do you think you're going?
Well, if we can send, it's the only thing I can do.
You've no idea what conditions are like up there.
I know all too well what they're like down here. And it's my job to put things right.
Miss Kelly! You cannot assume that responsibility without authorisation.
Commander, you've stopped me once. Please don't try it again, otherwise I shall have to go above your head.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly leaves.

Dialogue.Line: She's after your job, Julian.
Miss Kelly! She's a fool. If we lose her, nothing can save us.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In the store room, Phipps has got three infra red lamps set up, pointing at the middle of the room, and plugged into the amplifier. He plugs that into the solar power line.
Meanwhile, in the main control room, Fewsham staring at the T Mat cubicle and waiting. Kelly and two technicians appear.

Dialogue.Line: Thank heavens you've come.
What happened?
Osgood. It must have been space madness. He just went berserk, raving mad. It was terrifying.
Osgood? But he'd be the last man I'd have thought
So did we.
Where are the others?
When Osgood fused the controls, Locke tried to stop him. Osgood killed him.
This is fantastic! What about Phipps?
Well, he was injured too. I've put him under sedation.
And you?
There's nothing wrong with me.
You look frightened.
If you'd seen Osgood die, wouldn't you be?
How did he die?
His body's outside. He just went out.
Without a pressure suit? I see. Open all control sections and computer links. Fewsham, what are you doing?
I thought I'd best switch off the emergency link. With the trouble we've got it could easily burn itself out.
Sensible. Anyway, it'll prevent Commander Radnor sending up a security guard to drag me back to Reception Earth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Out of sight of the humans, Slaar gives his Warrior the usual order.

Dialogue.Line: The other human is still free. Find him. He must not interfere with our plans.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps has found a transmitter unit, and unplugs the infra-red array to power it.

Dialogue.Line: Hello, Earth Control this is Moonbase. Emergency. Emergency. How do you read me? Hello Earth Control, this is Moonbase. Emergency. Can you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps takes the back off the transmitter unit.

Dialogue.Line: It's no use. No contact at all. Every circuit's dead.
Oh dear, this is most unfortunate.
Aye, well don't try them again. You may blow the whole rocket up next time.
Well, there's no use worrying about the radio now. We're nearly at the end of the journey.
Well I had hoped we could stay in contact with Earth.
We don't need them. All we have to do is activate the Moon homing beam.
Well, how do you do that? I thought we weren't in contact with anyone on the Moon?

Well, it's quite simple, Jamie. It's an automatic device. We send out code radio signals which triggers the homing beacon into action. We automatically lock onto it until we reach the point in orbit where we fire retro-rockets to land.
Oh. Ah, but if they've all been cut off, how can they activate?
It works off a different power source, Jamie. Solar power. It's independent of the T-Mat system.
Aye well, I just hope it works, that's all.
Well, if it doesn't we're going to have trouble docking at Moon Control airlock. It could be quite a crash.
What?
Well, lets try, shall we? I think we're near enough. There, that's our activating signal.
That's it. As long as that note is steady, we're home and dry, no trouble at all.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The homing beam light has lit up on the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Hello Earth Control, this is Moonbase. Emergency. Emergency. Can you hear me? Hello Earth Control, this is Moonbase. Emergency. Emergency. Can you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A Warrior in the corridor hears Phipps raise his voice.

Dialogue.Line: Hello Earth Control. This is Moonbase. Emergency! Can you hear me? Hello Earth Control. This is Moonbase. Can you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hello Earth Control.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps hears the Warrior behind him and quickly swaps the transmitter power for the infra red array. The room is filled with the light, and when Phipps switches off again, the Ice Warrior is just a dirty patch on the floor. Phipps plugs the transmitter back in.

Dialogue.Line: Hello Earth Control. This is Moonbase. Emergency. Emergency. Can you hear me?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The light on the rocket homing beam indicator has gone out.

Dialogue.Line: Hello Earth Control. This is Moonbase. Emergency. Emergency. Can you hear me?
At our present rate of drift and allowing for the usual gravitational influences, we'll be drawn into the heart of the sun in approximately five months and ten days.
No need to worry about that, then.
What do you mean?
We've only got enough food and water for three days, remember? (The Doctor hears something over his headset.)
Just a minute. I think I'm getting something.
Hello Earth Control, this is Moonbase. Emergency. Emergency. Can you hear me?
Hello, Moonbase. Can you hear me?
Yes! Yes, I can hear you load and clear. What part of Earth are you speaking from?
We're not on the Earth. We're in a rocket orbiting the moon.
A rocket? But that's impossible!
Well I can assure you it's not impossible. What is your emergency? What's happening on Moonbase?
We've been invaded. Aliens have taken over.
Put that cover back on. Right, let's test it now.
Do you really think it will work?
No reason why not. We've replaced the overloaded circuits. It should be all right. Turn on the power. Hold it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly adjusts something near the monitor.

Dialogue.Line: Try again. We'll T-Mat back to Earth and report to Commander Radnor.
Stop! You will remain here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Ice Warriors hem them in.

Dialogue.Line: Don't move! Do exactly as they say!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A technician runs for the T-Mat cubicle and gets killed. The other tackles a warrior and also dies.

Dialogue.Line: You will remain here.
Brent, has contact be re-established with Moonbase yet?
No, sir. As soon as Miss Kelly was transmitted the emergency link switched off again.
And you've no idea what's happened?
Oh, I'm sure Miss Kelly will sort things out all right.
I wish I had your optimism.
How much longer, Zoe?
Well, our orbit will bring us back into his range in approximately forty three seconds.
Let's hope he can still transmit.
Well, his signal was quite strong when we were orbiting his side of the moon. There's no reason for it to fade.
It's not his equipment I'm worried about, it's his survival.
Doctor, these aliens he described.
How much did you hear?
Bipeds, reptilian, armed with some kind of sonic device.
Yes, Ice Warriors.
What?
Yes, yes. Jamie and I have met them before. They come from the planet Mars.
Well, what do they want?
Mars is a dying planet. I imagine they're trying to find a new home.
Why the Moon?
Oh, I think that that's just a stepping stone.
What did you they were? Ice Warriors?
Yes.
Yes. Well Mars, as you know, is a cold planet. They've adapted to that. It's heat they can't stand.
We should just about be coming into range now.
Hello Moonbase, hello Moonbase. Can you read me?
Yes, I read you loud and clear.
Oh thank heavens for that. Now listen. We need your help to make a landing.
But you mustn't land. You must warn Earth about what's happened here.
We can't do that. We've lost radio contact with the Earth.
Well then, go back and warn them.
We can't do that either. We haven't got enough fuel. We need to get to the fuel dump on the moon.
But they'll kill you!
Oh well, we'll just have to take that risk. Now, where are you Mister, er, what's?
Phipps. I'm in the Solar Energy Store. Now, what do you want me to do?
Doctor, if we could adapt our homing equipment to his radio signal, we could beam in on that.
Did you hear that? We want you to keep your transmitter going.
All right, I'll try, but I've no idea how long this transmitter can last.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor fastens some wires together.

Dialogue.Line: There, I think that's done it. Now then, let's see if we can pick up his signal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Beep beep beep.

Dialogue.Line: Yes. Yes, there we are. Now, Zoe, what about the approach trajectory?
Yes, here.
Ah good. Oh yes. Oh, I don't think I could have done better myself.
We need to fire the retro-rockets in seventeen point five seconds.
What? Well, landing positions, everyone.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They turn their seats around.

Dialogue.Line: Two seconds, one, now.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor flicks the Retro Rockets switch and the craft turns to head tail first for the moon.

Dialogue.Line: Let's hope there's enough fuel left to cushion down on.
Aye, and let's hope that radio beam thing doesn't conk out before we get there.
Don't worry, Jamie. I'm sure we're going to be all right.
Hello Moon rocket. Can you hear me?
Hello Moonbase. Yes, we can. We are coming in on your signal now. Whatever you do, keep transmitting.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: One of the diodes on top of the transmitter goes out. Of course.

Dialogue.Line: The signal! It's stopped!
Can you get us back into orbit?
No! No, I shall have to get us down as best I can.
But if we crash into a mountain range, we'll be smashed to pieces!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps replaces the failed diode.

Dialogue.Line: It's working again. Doctor, can you lock back onto it?
Well, I'll try. Yes, yes, there it is. Oh, my word. I think we're going to be all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The entire craft comes down vertically onto the Moonbase pad with something of a bump.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, well, I'm sorry about the landing. Is everyone all right?
Aye, well, we're down, that's that main thing.
Yes.
Now what do we do?
Well, the first we must do is to refuel. You can see to that, Zoe, can't you.
Yes, but what are you going to do?
Well I must go in search of Mister Phipps.
But what about the Ice Warriors?
Oh, I've met them before.
But Doctor, you can't just go

Well I've got to rescue Mister Phipps, now haven't I? Now where did I put that map of. Ah. Here we are. Now then, the Solar Power room is. Here we are. Oh yes. Oh yes, that seems to be quite a simple route.
Right, I'll come with you.
No. You'll stay here and look after Zoe. Now don't worry, you're going to be quite all right.
Ah.
Good luck.
And to you.
And to you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaves the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: Well, how do we refuel?
Oh, well, that's simple. It'll connect automatically from here. Now you watch this dial, and when it reads full, switch it off. Now do you think you can remember that?
Of course I can.
Good. I want to have a look at the rocket motors.
Why, what's the matter?
Well I didn't much like the way we landed. It could have caused some damage.
Well, I know it was a bit rough, but surely it wasn't as bad as all that?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie helps her down a service ladder.

Dialogue.Line: Well, it's not the landing that matters now, it's the take-off.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham is pressing buttons next to city names.

Dialogue.Line: Tokyo. London. Canberra. That's the lot. The whole system's completely operational again.
We can now send to any city in the world?
Yes, anywhere there's a T-Mat centre.
Fewsham, do you realise what you're doing?
I'm trying to save our lives.
And what about the people on Earth?
We're in no position to argue.
Why do you want control of T-Mat? If you're going to invade the Earth, you'll be fighting the armed forces of the entire world. You'll never succeed. There'll be too much resistance.
There will be no resistance.
What about us? What'll happen to us?
You will remain alive as long as you are useful.
You'll never get any help from me.
When the time comes you will do exactly what you are told, or die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sneaks down corridors, following his map. He taps on the store room door and enters.

Dialogue.Line: Hello?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps comes out from behind a box, wrench in hand.

Dialogue.Line: Who are you?
Oh! Oh, Mister Phipps, I presume?
Yes, but where'd you come from?
From the rocket. We were talking on the radio.
Thank heavens you made it. Are the others here too?
No, they're still in the rocket. How many of the Ice Warriors are there?
These creatures, you mean?
Yes.
Well, there aren't many, but they're deadly.
Oh, they have their weak points.
Look, they've killed everybody here. All except Fewsham. He's helping them.
I see. Well, there's only one thing for it. We shall have to destroy T-Mat.
What!
Are you all right, Doctor?
Yes. Have you refuelled the rocket, Jamie?
Yes, we've just finished and Zoe's checking the rocket motors.
Oh good. I have found Mister Phipps.
How is he?
Oh, he's quite all right but
Aye, and you're bringing him back now?
Yes, eventually, Jamie, but I've got to put T-Mat out of action first.
But, but, but Doctor, what about the Ice Warriors?
Now, don't worry. Jamie. You and Zoe prepare the rocket for take off and wait for us. Goodbye.
But Doctor. Doctor. Hey! Och.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe climbs up into the capsule.

Dialogue.Line: That was the Doctor. He's found Phipps and he wants us to prepare the rocket for take off while they put T-Mat out of action.
But he can't!
Why?
I've just checked the main power drive and the rocket's motors are completely useless.
What?
The only way back to Earth is by T-Mat.
Oh!
Doctor? Doctor, can you hear me? This is Zoe. Doctor! Oh he must have switched off!
Oh, now what do we do?
We'll go and find him. Come on.
Where is this leading to?
Control Headquarters. Through this way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Round a corner they see a Warrior with Kelly in its painful grasp.

Dialogue.Line: It's an Ice Warrior. It's got Miss Kelly. But how?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior aims its weapon at them.

Dialogue.Line: Run!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps and the Doctor run different ways. Kelly gets free of the Warrior and runs after Phipps. The Doctor reappears and tackles the Warrior before leading it off on a diversion through various corridors. Just as he thinks he has lost it, two more are in front of him. He runs back through an area of mirrored panels that cast lots of reflections until he is trapped in front of a locked door.

Dialogue.Line: Stop!
You must be destroyed.
You've got no orders to kill me. Your leader will want to speak to me!
Humans are our enemies!
But I can be useful to you, like Fewsham. Your leader will be angry if you kill me. I'm a genius.
Genius? You will come with me.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Meanwhile, Jamie and Zoe don't have the benefit of a map.

Dialogue.Line: Now which way?
I don't know. I'm lost.
I thought you knew the way.
So did I. Let's try this way.
Women!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They come to another junction.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, no. We could wander around here all day.
Listen! Quick, here!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hide behind a stanchion as a Warrior comes past.

Dialogue.Line: What was that thing?
An Ice Warrior. You see, we were right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior turns.

Dialogue.Line: Quick, run.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe run down another corridor and hide again.

Dialogue.Line: Get back. Don't move.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior looks down the corridor then takes another one.

Dialogue.Line: Now what do we do?
Keep looking for the Doctor and keep your eyes open for the solar energy room. Come on.
Solar energy.
I wish you'd tell me what you want me to do.
You will shortly dispatch a cargo to certain cities on Earth. They will include Ottawa, Oslo, Stockholm, Hamburg.
Cargo? What sort of cargo?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warriors enter with the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: The prisoner Kelly has escaped. This human was in the corridors.
Who are you? Where are you from?
I might ask you the same question.
You will find the human Kelly and bring her back here. Who is this man?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warriors leave.

Dialogue.Line: He's not one of the crew. I don't know him. He must have just arrived here.
Impossible. We control T-Mat. How did you get here?
Our resources are not limited to T-Mat, you know.
You arrived here by other means, by spacecraft?
Rockets haven't been used for years.
Then you are lying. You have been concealed here all the time.
But you can't be sure of that, can you? The people of the Earth may be preparing a whole fleet of rockets to defend themselves with.
No. Earth relies entirely on T-Mat. There is no defence against our plans.
And what are your plans? Invasion by T-Mat? There are too few of you to conquer all the peoples of the Earth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two Warriors carry an opaque container between them.

Dialogue.Line: The Grand Marshal has ordered all the seeds to be prepared. You are to receive your instructions.
Then guard the humans. If they try to escape, kill them.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Slaar leaves. The Warriors busy themselves with the container, so the Doctor speaks quietly to Fewsham.

Dialogue.Line: Why are you helping them?
I've seen what they can do.
Do you know what is in that container?
All I know is they want me to send something to Earth by T-Mat. I suppose that's what's in it.
Then I shall have to have a look inside, and you are going to help me.
The Doctor's been captured? But couldn't you help him?
I'm sorry. There was nothing we could do.
We had a job to reach here ourselves.
Aye, so did we.
Are you sure the Ice Warriors don't know about this place?
Well, one of them did find it, but I managed to deal with him.
How?
Well, I fixed up a kind of booby trap to the solar energy power line.
Ah.
By the look of those things I'd have though they were invulnerable.
No. The Doctor said they can't stand heat.
Aye, that's right.
The heating system of the entire base is controlled from the Centre. Now if we could reach those controls and turn up the heating.
But how can we get there? There are Ice Warriors patrolling those corridors.
Aye.
Yes I know. The maintenance tunnels. Over here.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A grill in the wall.

Dialogue.Line: Hey, if we could get through here, then turn the heating up, knock the Warriors out, we could rescue the Doctor.
And T-Mat ourselves back to Earth.
Aye.
But I thought T-Mat had broken down?
Not anymore. I repaired it. How can we get this cover off?
This part of the base hasn't been used for ages. It's rusted solid. It'll take some time.
Aye, well, the Doctor may not have much time.
(sotto) All right, Fewsham. Now.
I can't! They'll kill us both!
You have got to help me.
I said I can't.
Very well, I shall do it by myself. If I'm caught, which is most likely, we will both get killed.
All right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham walks past a Warrior.

Dialogue.Line: Do not move!
I was ordered to prepare the controls for transmission. I've have got to check that everything is in order.
Return to where you were.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor sneaks over to the container.

Dialogue.Line: But this is most important!
If you are trying to escape, I shall destroy you.
I'm not trying to escape.
Go back to where you were.
All right, all right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior sees the Doctor at the container. We hear it slam shut as the Doctor turns and raises his hands.

Dialogue.Line: Wait! Open it. I said open it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The container is full of six inch spheres.

Dialogue.Line: What are these things? (he picks one up) They look like seed pods.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pod suddenly expands, goes pop and the Doctor coughs on the tiny particles it releases. He collapses.

Dialogue.Line: What is it? What's happened to him? Is he dead?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps and Jamie work at opening the grill to the maintenance tunnels. Zoe listens at the door.

Dialogue.Line: That's it!
I think I heard something.
Be careful!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe opens the door and looks out to see a Warrior in the corridor.

Dialogue.Line: There's one coming. I don't think he saw me.
We won't take any chances.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie jams a metal bar across the sliding door.

Dialogue.Line: That should hold it.
Get back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone hides.

Dialogue.Line: Don't move.
The booby trap thing, does it still work?
It'll have to be reconnected.
Well, come on.
Miss Kelly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly plugs the infra red lamps back into the extension cable.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe hands him the power plug.

Dialogue.Line: (hanging on to the door) Hurry up!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps plugs the array into the solar-power line.

Dialogue.Line: Right!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie lets go of the door handle and the Warrior enters.

Dialogue.Line: Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps throws the switch, and a few seconds later there is another dirty mark on the floor.
A Warrior carries a seed pod towards the T-Mat.

Dialogue.Line: You will prepare to activate the cubicle and transmit to London. Obey!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham sits at the controls.

Dialogue.Line: Emergency transport systems now in operation. However situation still extremely critical in most parts of the world. Primitive areas surviving best but all major cities now suffering severe food shortages.
Without T-Mat, millions are going to die, especially in the cities.
Activate!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The seed pod and its elegant stand vanish.

Dialogue.Line: The thing's alive!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pod goes pop and spreads its fine contents into the air. Brent gets a lungful of it in the cubicle and collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Get away from here. Quick, quick!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Everyone else runs away, coughing.

Dialogue.Line: He's dead. Keep back. It must be that smoke. Guards! Keep away from here! (the cubicle)
Use the air conditioning!
Switch the air conditioning to expel.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A technician obeys and the fine smoke or particles are sucked out through the grill.

Dialogue.Line: It seems to be clearing. What was that thing?
Careful, Daniel.
It's all right. It's harmless enough now. It's shrivelled up.
Get Brent's body over to the medical wing. Tell them that I want a full autopsy.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Technicians carry Brent away.

Dialogue.Line: Now what do you make of that?
Ever seen anything like that thing before?
No. It looked like some sort of seed pod, but why do you think it exploded like that?
Some plants reproduce that way. Their pods explode and spread their seeds.
All this thing spread was some kind of smoke.
Which has now been dispelled into the air of London.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Ottawa light is flashing. A Warrior brings another pod from the container to the T Mat cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Prepare to dispatch. Dispatch.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Oslo light flashes and another pod is fetched.

Dialogue.Line: Hamburg.
Why are we doing this? What are those things?
Dispatch!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly is working on one of the infra red lamps.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe, would you hold this for a moment? (the bulb)
What is it?
Well, this circuit was overloaded. It blew out when we destroyed that creature. I'm trying to repair it. Okay.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe gives the bulb back.

Dialogue.Line: Well, this one looks all right.
Let's hope it works.
Well, let's hope we don't need it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe checks the maintenance tunnel.

Dialogue.Line: There's no sign of them. It isn't getting any warmer, is it.
Well they can't have had time to reach the heating controls yet.
And the heating controls are in the main control room, aren't they.
Yes.
And so are the Ice Warriors.
Are you all right?
Fine.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps and Jamie come to a grill where they can see into the control room and the T Mat cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Paris. Dispatch!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Another pod is on its way.

Dialogue.Line: What are they up to?
I don't know. It looks as though they're sending something by T-Mat.
Who's that helping them?
Fewsham.
Hey, can you see the Doctor anywhere?
No, there's no sign of him. I wonder what it is they're sending?

The object appeared in reception cubicle T-Mat headquarters. Leading Technician Douglas D Grant in close proximity to the object collapsed and died instantly. Cause of death as yet unknown. Message from New York ends.
That's another one. How many does that make?
Sixteen T-Mat reception centres.
How many deaths?
Brent here, that man in Berlin, two in New York. But I doubt if those things were sent just to kill one or two people at random.
What else then?
Well, I don't know, but
What?
I'm wondering if there's any pattern with these cities. London, Ottawa, Oslo, Hamburg, Berlin.
Yes, they're all major population centres, certainly.
But is that all they have in common?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A printout arrives at the control panel.

Dialogue.Line: What is it?
The autopsy report on Brent.
Well?
He died of oxygen starvation.
Oxygen starvation takes at least three or four minutes. He died instantly.
Exactly. And according to this the medical unit can't believe it either.

Obviously what killed him was that smoke-like substance which was emitted when the pods exploded, which was expelled into the outside atmosphere. Let's hope that diluted with air it loses it's toxic quality, otherwise

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The pod's particles drift like mist in the wind, but where they touch the ground they quickly 'foam' up into bubbles which then burst and release more particles.

Dialogue.Line: Zurich. Dispatch!
Is that the last?
It may be necessary to send further seeds later.
What about him?
Is he still alive?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is still out cold face down on the floor. Patrick Troughton is on holiday this week.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, he's still breathing.
That is unusual. Most humans would be dead. Take him to the T-Mat cubicle.
What for?
Do as I say.
What are they going to do?
Shush!
Dispose of him.
What do you mean?
You will adjust the T-Mat controls and suspend him in space between the moon and Earth.
We've got to try and save him.
Back of the cubicle. Over here, quick.
But you can't just ask me to kill a man just like that.
You dispatched the seeds. In so doing you destroyed your entire species.
Oh, no!
What is the death of one man compared to that?
What was in those things?
No more questions. Operate the controls.
I can't. I can't!
Prefer to die.
T-Mat is only programmed to send to other centres. I shall have to reprogramme the circuit.
Then do so at once.
Are you sure this is the back of the right cubicle?
It'd better be.
Well?
Please. Please don't make me.
Complete it!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps and Jamie remove a grill.

Dialogue.Line: Right.
Oh no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: There is a second grill.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, it's only the interior casing. It comes away easily.
Oh.
Is the circuit prepared yet?
Yes, almost. Almost.
You are wasting time. Operate.
No!
At once!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham reaches for a switch. The T-Mat cubicle is empty.

Dialogue.Line: You've killed him. You've killed him! You've killed him!
Prepare to dispatch to London. Do as I say!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Slaar goes over to a Warrior.

Dialogue.Line: The time has come for your mission. You understand what you must do?
I understand.
You must succeed at all costs.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior goes into a cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Transmit to London.
I need time. I must reprogramme.
Can you manage the Doctor by yourself?
Yes.
Can you remember the way back?
Oh, I think so.
I'll try and get to the heating controls.
Good.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Phipps makes his way up an access ladder and around the back of the control room. From another grill he can see the heating controls on the wall opposite, looking like a ship's wheel. He tries to get through an access plate but his shoulders are too wide.
Back on Earth, the spores are spreading and reproducing rapidly, covering the ground with a mass of foam.

Dialogue.Line: Reports now received on cause of death of T-Mat reception technicians in New York and Berlin. In all cases victims died of oxygen starvation.
Discontinue report.
Wait a minute. There's something else.
All right. Continue report.
Information coming in on appearance of vegetable blight now attacking parks and gardens in the metropolises. Many areas

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior bursts out of the T-Mat cubicle. Technicians flee as it moves towards them.

Dialogue.Line: Unidentified menace. Foam appears to be byproduct of large fungi which grow and burst, spreading their spores over large areas. Rate of growth of fungi such that acres of ground are covered minutes. Estimated that strong south westerly winds could spread this disease over large areas of Europe and Asia.
Guards!
Destroying second crop cereals.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A guard rushes in, firing. The Warrior uses its own weapon on him then walks out into the corridor where there is more gunfire. Radnor picks up the dead guard's gun and goes into the corridor. The Warrior's weapon can be heard. Radnor returns.

Dialogue.Line: The guards. It's killed them. It's killed them all!
I shall return shortly. You will remain here. (to another Warrior) The humans that escaped, have they been found?
We are searching for them.
Intensify the search. They must be found and destroyed. Guard him.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor is lying on a table, his face turned away from us.

Dialogue.Line: How is he?
I think the water helped him.
Aye, well, we'd better get back there. We've still got to get those heating control things.
It's no good, Jamie, we'll never make it.
Why not?
Because the ventilator's too small and there's no other way.
Well, maybe I could get through.
Look, it's impossible.
How big is this grill?
About so big.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe steps between his hands.

Dialogue.Line: Well I could get through.
No, Zoe. You're not going.
Look, I'm smaller than you and I'll probably be a lot quieter too.
Look, it's too dangerous anyway.
Well, what other alternative is there?
Well.
She's right. It's the logical thing to do.
Thank you. Well come on, show me the way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior walks through the exploding pods outside.

Dialogue.Line: He can't just have vanished.
I can assure you that the security guards have lost all trace of it.
I wonder what its purpose was?
Purpose? What are you talking about?
Well, can't you see it's all part of the same plan. First the seed pods and now this creature. I tell you it came here for some purpose, and heaven help anyone who gets in its way.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Some defence technicians are spraying the foam, trying to kill it. They get covered in it but are wearing breathing apparatus. The Warrior advances. It kills one and the others flee.

Dialogue.Line: Any trace yet of the alien creature?
Reports from security negative.
There you are, what did I tell you.
Security reports cordon round T-Mat complex unbroken.
At least we know it's still in the area.
Correction. Urgent message. Bodies of three technicians found in T-Mat grounds.
Which way now?
I'm not sure.
But you must remember. You've already been this way once with Jamie.
Yes, I know, but I can't remember this time.
But surely
Look, I can't remember! All the tunnels look the same.
Are you all right?
Oh yes, I'm fine. I've seen most of my friends killed. I'm being hunted by monsters.
If you go on shouting like that, you'll be caught by them and so will I.
I'm sorry. I don't know what's the matter with me.
It's nervous exhaustion and a slight touch of claustrophobia. Just sit down and we'll have a rest.
I tell you that creature came here for some purpose. It must be making for somewhere. Somewhere in this area.
Urgent message. Contact made with security guard observing the alien.
Relay report direct.
Report to Central control.
Report to Central control. The creature is entering the east compound area.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior sees the guard who making the report. He starts to run, but is too late.

Dialogue.Line: What's happened? Report.
What's happened? Report!
Security guard's ceased transmission.
Tell Security I want a armed patrol sent to the east command area without fail. Immediately. And relay any findings to me here direct. Top priority.
You're only going to lose more security guards.
Well, I can't let that creature roam loose, can I?

Can we stop it? Do you know how we can stop it? You know that bullets will do no good. We've seen that for ourselves. In all these cities that. Wait a moment. Yes! Oslo, Ottawa, Berlin, Hamburg, London, Paris, New York! These are the places where the pods have arrived.
Well, so what?
Well, don't you see? They're all cold climates. All northern hemisphere. In all of those cities it's winter, as it is here.
So?
Why haven't the pods arrived in any warm areas?
Urgent message. Subject, continued breakdown of T-Mat and cessation of all world transport and distribution. Total breakdown of social order predicted. Emergency measures proving inadequate.
Discontinue report.
Incoming data will be recorded.
Well, the emergency measures may still save a few people.
Well, what's the good of that? With the dislocation of food supplies, we could lose millions.
We may lose most of the world's population before they've finished with us.
They?
This creature. It's only the first. We're going to be invaded!
Any sign of them?
No.
They've been gone ages. They can't have reached the heating controls yet. The temperature seems the same.
Look, I'm going down there.
No, our job is to act as a rearguard in case something goes wrong.
Look, a lot of good we are.
Well, we're not entirely helpless.
You've got that thing working again?
I think so, but we can hardly test it.
Oh look, where are they? What's keeping them?
I think we ought to go on.
All right.
Look, can you remember the way now?
No, it's no good.
We could work it out.
How?
Well, presumably these maintenance tunnels run parallel to the corridors.
Well, yes they do, but.
Well, I've seen a map of the corridors. The Doctor had one in the rocket.
But you can't possibly remember
Yes I can, I think. Now there's a main corridor here, the two junctions here. We went left, right, left. It must be that one.
But you and Jamie got lost on the way to the solar energy storeroom.
Well, only temporarily, I found the way eventually.
Well, you'd better be right this time.
Oh come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A little later, Zoe and Phipps are looking into the Control room.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, how long is it going to stand there?
I don't know. But I daren't move the grille until it goes.
Look, I'd better see what's happened to them.
All right, but
What?
Shush. Quick, the door!
Too late!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: As Warrior enters.

Dialogue.Line: (silent) Now!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly turns on the solar power line but nothing happens.

Dialogue.Line: (silent) Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior turns to leave then returns.

Dialogue.Line: (silent) Keep back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior goes over to the Doctor, still lying on the table.

Dialogue.Line: He's moving.
Quick, move the grille!
How much longer must I wait here?
Do not ask questions!
I need food, rest. I haven't had any sleep for hours.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham spots Zoe and Phipps peering out of the grille.

Dialogue.Line: What are you doing?
I must fix the cubicle.
But you said T-Mat was functioning properly.
I know, but there's something I've forgotten.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior follows Fewsham, with its back to the grille.

Dialogue.Line: Quick! Now the heating controls are over there. Turn the main wheel to full.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham finally acts, and tries to deflect the Warrior's aim away from Zoe. It knocks him away as Zoe stands frozen in fear. The temperature is climbing up to forty degrees C, and the Warrior suddenly puts its claws to its head and collapses. Zoe runs over to Fewsham.

Dialogue.Line: Are you all right?
Yes, I am. Who are you? What are you doing here?
Oh, never mind that. I thought you were on their side.
Is that what they all think?
Well, you have been helping them, haven't you.
I had no alternative. They'd have killed me.
Well look, where are the other Ice Warriors?
I think they've gone to their ship, but they'll be coming back. We must get out of here.
Oh but how?
Look, I can get you back to Earth. T-Mat is working again.
Oh! Well, I'll get back to the others and tell them the good news.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior is about to leave when the Doctor starts groaning.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, Victoria, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior walks past Jamie's hiding place and he smashes down on its weapon with a metal bar. It throws him across the room so Kelly has a go too. She is easily thrown off and it grabs Jamie's wrists.

Dialogue.Line: No!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The thermometer passes fifty degrees C and the Warrior collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, well done, Jamie.
Are you all right?
Yes, I think so. Oh, I'm a bit dizzy. It's so hot in here.
Aye, lucky for us. Zoe and Phipps turned the heating up just in time.
What? Well, where are they now?
They went though the maintenance tunnel to the main control room.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe enters through the hatch.

Dialogue.Line: Ah, Zoe!
Oh Doctor! (they hug) Oh, are you all right?
Yes, I think so.
Good.
Where's Phipps?
He's dead. An Ice Warrior killed him.
How did you manage to escape?
That other man helped me.
Fewsham?
Yes.
Well I thought that he was working for them.
He saved my life.
Doesn't sound much like Fewsham.
He attacked a Warrior. He's also got T-Mat working again.
Well, do I gather we can get back to Earth then?
Yes, I think so.
Well, let's not waste any more time.
No. Come on.
Well, that's all we need.
What is it?
Gregson's here.
Gregson, eh?
Sir James Gregson.
United Nations Plenipotentiary.
Minister with special responsibility for T-Mat.
And your boss, in other words!
Oh, don't.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: An older man enters and hands his briefcase to Radnor.

Dialogue.Line: Radnor, I've read your report. I can't make head nor tail of it. Who's this?
Professor Eldred, sir.
How do you do.
Oh well.
He's helping me, sir.
This breakdown of T-Mat. What is the position now?
Still no contact yet with Moonbase, sir.
And what are you doing about it?
We've got people up there.
How'd you get them there without T-Mat?
We sent a rocket, sir. Professor Eldred is an expert in rocketry.
Oh, I see. And what happened to the rocket?
It's rather difficult to say, sir. We lost radio contact with it soon after take-off.
Is that all you've done?
Oh no. No, my Chief Technician, Miss Kelly, has also gone to Moonbase.
Oh, more rockets.
No, sir, she went by T-Mat.
But T-Mat isn't working.
Well, T-Mat started to function again, sir, so Miss Kelly went to the Moonbase with a repair team.
So you've had a full report from her?
Well, no, sir. Soon after take off T-Mat ceased to function again.
But this is quite ridiculous. T-Mat out of action and then this sudden outbreak of some sort of crop blight.
Ah, now, you see, sir, we think that's connected
As for this incredible story about a monster from outer-space
Well you see, Sir James, I think I owe you an explanation.
What happened about this creature? Have you any more news?
No, it seems to have completely disappeared. It was reported here, then it was seen by some workmen in a building here, and the last sighting was by the Weather Control Bureau there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior walks through the foam to the Weather Control building and forces its way inside. The duty weatherman tries to run but is killed. It then goes to a convenient Weather Control Unit and moves all the levers to 'Dry', then uses its weapon on it, fusing the controls in place.

Dialogue.Line: But I had to help them or they would have killed me!
All right, Fewsham. There'll be a full inquiry when we get back to Earth. Tell them. We've no more time to waste here. We must T-Mat back to Earth immediately.
But if we're all going, who is going to dispatch us?
Look, there's a way of doing that. Here. This is a time switch. It delays transportation by ten seconds.
Oh, I see. How ingenious.
Now I'll dispatch you, and follow using the time switch.
Righto. Jamie, Zoe, come along. I think this could be quite fun, you know.
Oh.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe get into a cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Fewsham, that time switch was down on the maintenance report as being inoperable.
We repaired it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Zoe and Jamie vanish.

Dialogue.Line: In you get, Miss Kelly. Look, I'll use the time switch. You'd better hurry or those Ice Warriors could be back any minute.
You know, I find T-Mat travel rather disappointing. There's no sensation at all.
Where have you been?
Ah.
And what have you been up to all this time?
Well
And where's Miss Kelly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly appears in the T-Mat cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Miss Kelly! Miss Kelly, what's happening up there?
Will somebody kindly tell me what's happening down here? Who are these people? Is T-Mat working again?
Please! Let us answer one question at a time.
Doctor, do you know there's been a alien here?
An Ice Warrior, here?
Jamie, I am not surprised. They have taken over the whole of the Moonbase.
What about the crew?
All dead except Fewsham.
You left him there?
Well he said he'd follow using the time switch.
He should be back.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly goes to the control panel.

Dialogue.Line: What's happening?
I thought so. The time switch is out of order.
What? But he said he was going to repair it.
He was lying.
But why?
Well, he's obviously working for them.
Then why did he let us escape?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham is waiting. As soon as he hears Slaar's breathing he pretends to be unconscious across the control desk. Slaar staggers in and goes over to the temperature control. Fewsham follows him. Slaar turns the temperature down to cold.

Dialogue.Line: What has happened here?
The others, they got in through the grille and turned up the heating.
Where are they now?
They went back to Earth by T-Mat.
Why did you not go with them?
I refused. That's why they attacked me.
Refused? Why?
What do you think would have happened to me back on Earth? I'd have been executed as a traitor.
So you hope to live longer by staying here. You value your life. That is good. You will live if you help us when the invasion fleet arrives.
You're going to land on Earth?
No, our warriors will land here, on the moon. When the seed pods have done their work on Earth it will be time to commence the second stage of our plan.
But don't you see gentlemen? The invasion of Moonbase, the taking over of T-Mat, the seed pods, the arrival of the Ice Warrior. They're all part of the same plan.
Plan? What plan?
These incidents are so unrelated. This fungus everywhere, what's that got to do with it?
Well, I'm not sure yet. Have your people been able to make anything of it?
Well it's indestructible. We've attacked it in every possible way, but without success.
Yes, but have you tried to understand it?
Are you suggesting we should psychoanalyse it, Doctor?
I'm only suggesting that instead of trying to destroy it, you find out it's composition and purpose.
Well, there's laboratory equipment in my workshop. You could use that.
Good. Then we must find a sample.
Well, no problem about that. The gardens are full of the stuff.
Fine. Then there's no time to be lost.
I'll get some equipment for you.
Er, Doctor, do be careful. Those pod things are deadly.
Don't worry. I've already had experience. I'll be careful.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe and Jamie are sipping drinks while Kelly writes on a clip board.

Dialogue.Line: But why did Fewsham stay on the moon?
Pretty obvious. He was too afraid to come back here and face an inquiry.
But he wasn't afraid to stay up there with the Ice Warriors. Well, given the choice I know which I'd rather face.
Aye.
There's no time to worry about Fewsham. We must find a way of getting T-Mat working.
But I thought it was working again now.
It is working. It's still controlled from the moon. We must find a way of controlling it from the Earth.
But is that possible? Don't you need the moon as a relay?
There might be a way. I must talk to Commander Radnor about it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kelly leaves.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe, look, do you think the Doctor knows what he's doing messing about with that foam stuff?
Oh, don't worry, Jamie. He'll be all right.
Oh, yes.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Outside, the Doctor gets a sample of fungus on a spatula and puts it in a large glass container, oblivious to the bubble growing nearby. It bursts, and he leaps up in alarm. Covering his mouth with a large kerchief, he quickly scoops up foam with the container and runs.

Dialogue.Line: You really think it would work?
Well, it couldn't be as effective as the Moonbase, of course, which handles up to two million microwave channels simultaneously. The satellite would take just a few thousand.
But that'd be enough for vital food supplies.
But surely we can't use the normal communications satellites. They're not programmed for T-Mat.
No, we'd have to send up a specially programmed one.
But that would mean using a rocket, wouldn't it? I thought no one used them nowadays.
Not manned rockets, but we do send up satellites for communications.
How soon can you get one up?
Well I don't know. If it were given top priority.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Under a microscope cells divide rapidly.

Dialogue.Line: Yes, it's organic. It's alive. Definitely a fungus composition.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor picks up a molecular model.

Dialogue.Line: You're sure that this is correct?
As far as I can make out, it is.
A molecule of five atoms absorbs oxygen. You know, a complete blanket of this would reduce the oxygen content of the Earth's atmosphere quite drastically.
According to my calculations, to one twentieth of normal.
It would make the atmosphere of the Earth uninhabitable to the human race, but exactly like the atmosphere of Mars.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A beaker is foaming out onto the bench.

Dialogue.Line: Look at that. Even without vegetation to feed on, it's still active.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bubble grows.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
Look out, Doctor. If that thing explodes in here, the fumes will kill us. Come on, Doctor!
Just a minute, there must be some way of

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor puts his kerchief over his mouth and starts pouring liquids onto the bubble.

Dialogue.Line: Come on, before its too late!
Sulphuric acid. Hydrochloric acid. Acetic acid.
Come on, Doctor!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor tips the contents of a large measuring glass over the bubble, and it starts to shrink.

Dialogue.Line: You've done it! Well, what was it? What did you throw on it?
Extensive search by security forces reveals no trace of alien creature. Message ends.
So that warrior's still roaming around loose somewhere.
But why did they only send one of them?
Well, perhaps he's got to report back somehow. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Is Commander Radnor there, please? Ah, Zoe! Is Radnor there?
