No, he's in conference with Miss Kelly and Sir James Gregson.
Oh, I see. Zoe, it's the most wonderful news. We've found a way of destroying the fungus.
Well, what is it?
Water. Ordinary water!
Eh?
Oh, but Doctor, surely ordinary
There's no time to explain now. Apparently there is a Weather Control Bureau somewhere. I want you to get in touch with them.
Well, can't you reach them on the video-phone?
Well, no. No, I've tried, but they're not answering or it's broken down or something.
What do you want me to do?
Well, get in touch with Commander Radnor and ask him to get hold of the Weather Control Bureau people and to make rain. As much rain as possible over the entire country.
All right, Doctor. I'll tell him.
Right. The Professor and I are coming back now.
Yes.
Bye.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: But Doctor, suppose that? Oh!
Hey, how do we get hold of Commander Radnor?
We'll ask the computer.
Do you know how it works?
Yes, of course. Put me in touch with Commander Radnor at once.
Commander Radnor engaged in top level T-Mat conference with Chief Technician Kelly and Sir James Gregson.
But this is urgent. I must talk to him at once!
Commander Radnor not available.
Oh, now what do we do?
We just have to go to the Weather Bureau ourselves.
We don't know where it is.
Well, we'll have to try and find it. Come on.
Oh, Zoe.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Two Warriors wheel in a fancy device with a small monitor set into it.

Dialogue.Line: There.
What is it?
Communications unit from our ship. Connect it to the solar batteries.
What's this section for?
That does not concern you.
I can't connect equipment if I don't know its purpose.
It transmits a directional beam signal.
A homing device. You'll use it to guide your armada onto the moon?
You will not ask questions. You will do as you are told!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe pick their way around the side of the building avoiding the foam which is creeping ever nearer to the open main door, and go inside.

Dialogue.Line: Hadn't we better close the door?
Why?
In case that warrior's still prowling around out there.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They push the door closed and the foam piles up against it outside. Jamie turns a knob to lock it.

Dialogue.Line: That should keep him out. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They go down some steps.

Dialogue.Line: Well, where is everybody?
I don't know. Well, let's try and find the main control room. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The weatherman's body is still there.

Dialogue.Line: So that's why nobody answered the video-phone.
Hey, and look at that!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie tries to move the fused control unit levers.

Dialogue.Line: No, it's no good. They're locked in position.
Well, don't you see? It's what the Doctor said. Water. Rain. Well, it all makes sense now. They don't want it to rain on the fungus.
Well, shush! It's a warrior. Hide!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior's heavy breathing has preceded it again, and Jamie and Zoe are hidden by the time it enters.
Slaar is talking to his superior on their own monitor. The Grand Marshal has sequins on his helmet.

Dialogue.Line: Are all the preparations complete?

Yes, Grand Marshal. The seed pods have been dispatched to the cities of the Earth, and the Moonbase is in our hands. MARSHALL [on monitor]: Good. Our fleet is approaching the gravitational field of the moon. Is all prepared?
Everything is ready. I shall guide our ships in on the homing beam signal. MARSHALL [on monitor]: Fuel supplies are at marginal level. There must be no misjudgments.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Fewsham quietly switches on the video-link.
A rocket stands at a gantry.

Dialogue.Line: Final checkout routines under way.
I hope they know what they're doing. It's been years since we sent up a satellite.
Are you quite sure the communications aspects will function?
Yes. Once that satellite's up, T-Mat will be able to handle two thousand microwave channels.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Eldred and the Doctor enter.

Dialogue.Line: What's going on? Someone sending up a rocket?
Look, look! What the devil's happening?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The video-link shows the scene on the Moon.

Dialogue.Line: I don't know. It's, yes, Moon Control.
The sound, can you turn it up? FEWSHAM [on monitor]: Shouldn't we test the directional beam?
It is not necessary.
But it's operating on Moonbase power. I can't guarantee the pulsing rate will be the same.
Very well. Test it.
Commander Radnor, can this be recorded?
Well, yes.
Well quickly, man. It's vital!
The transmission coming in on the video machine is to be recorded.
Instructions understood. Transmission will be recorded. SLAAR [on monitor]: The device is operating. FEWSHAM [on monitor]: Wait a moment.
I must check the connections.
Why?
If the power fails we won't be able to guide the fleet onto the moon.
There must be no failures.
I realise the importance of that. If we overshoot the moon, nothing will stop them from going straight into an orbit around the sun.
They will not overshoot!
Of course not. But since their fuel supplies are at a marginal level, if anything did go wrong, they'd never be able to regain moon orbit.
This video device is operating. You have betrayed us!
Every word has bee heard on Earth!
Kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A warrior obeys. Earth Control sees Fewsham die, then Slaar has the video camera destroyed too.

Dialogue.Line: Countdown about to commence. Minus three minutes.
Cancel the launch!
Why? What do you mean?
We can use that satellite to mislead the Martian invasion fleet.
What?
Well, don't you see? Poor Fewsham deliberately let us overhear their homing signal. We can imitate that signal with a homing device of our own in the satellite!
Commander Radnor. Top priority message to satellite launching site. Cancel launch. Repeat, cancel launch!
Message understood.
If we can deflect their armada, half our battle is won.
But there's still all that fungus stuff everywhere.
We've solved that one. Plain ordinary H20. Water!
Water?! Well, all we need to do then is to make it rain.
Well, haven't you already done that? Haven't you been in touch with the Weather Control Bureau?
You've only just told me.
But I sent you a message over an hour ago. Didn't Zoe reach you?
No.
An hour ago we were in conference.
Oh, I see. Well, perhaps Zoe went to the Weather Control people herself?
Doctor, the Weather Control Bureau was the last place the warrior was sighted!
What?
I'll have a squad of security guards over there right away. Hadn't you better wait, Doctor?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor has left.

Dialogue.Line: Get me Security!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Kerchief over his mouth, the Doctor picks his way carefully to the door, which no longer has foam up against it until he gets there, then it is up to his shoulders. Bubbles grow and burst as he hammers on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe! Are you in there? Zoe!
Zoe! Jamie! Let me in!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior turns back from Zoe and Jamie's hiding place to investigate the noise.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe! Jamie! Zoe!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor moves out of the doorway to see a tidal wave of foam and bubbles bearing down.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor slips and disappears under the foam, then gets up to hammer again on the door.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe!
Let me in! Zoe! Jamie!
Are you in there, Jamie!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: With the Warrior heading for the entrance, Jamie and Zoe run from their hiding places.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, open the door!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and Zoe catch up with the Warrior near the Solar Energy Room. Jamie mouths instructions at Zoe. Sorry, I don't lip read. Zoe hides and Jamie circles round then leaps out in front of the Warrior.

Dialogue.Line: Hey!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie runs off. The Warrior fires its weapon but he's already gone. Zoe comes out of hiding and runs down another corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe! Jamie! If you're there, let me in!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A bubble forms next to him. Again.

Dialogue.Line: Oh no!
Jamie, Zoe, open this door!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe gets to the main door and starts to unlock it.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie? Zoe?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Finally Zoe heaves the door open, and a flood of foam pours in with the Doctor. They get the door closed again.

Dialogue.Line: Oh! Oh! Oh! Oh my word!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe pulls him away from the door.

Dialogue.Line: What? Where are we going?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: In a dry corridor.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, my word. Oh, that was a dangerous situation!
It still is, Doctor. There's an Ice Warrior in the building.
What? What about Jamie?
Well, he drew the warrior off so that I could let you in.
Oh. no. We must help him.
Oh no, Doctor, this way.
What?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie leads the Warrior back into the Control room, but there is nowhere to hide. It fires its weapon at him and he dodges around bits of equipment before going through another doorway and shutting it behind him. The Warrior tries to blast its way out. In a corridor -

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Jamie!
Oh Jamie, where's the Ice Warrior?
Well, I locked him in the room that we were trapped in.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hear the Warrior's weapon firing.

Dialogue.Line: I don't think he's stayed in there, Jamie. Come on!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They return to outside the Solar Energy Room.

Dialogue.Line: Oh look, we could hide in here.
We'd just be trapped again.
No, Jamie, I think this is just the place.
Why?
Solar energy room. That means that's a radiation door. Now, if I can find the control.
Oh Doctor, hurry!
It must be here somewhere.
What do you mean?
Ah, wait a minute.
Is that the one?

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie throws a switch on the wall and the room goes dark.

Dialogue.Line: No, Jamie! (switches the lights on again) It must be one of these.
Oh hurry, Doctor!
Ah! There we are. It's got 'shut' on it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The door closes in the Warrior's face.

Dialogue.Line: Oh!
Get back!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior fires at the door.

Dialogue.Line: He's trying to blast his way in!
Well, it should hold for a little while, Jamie.
Well, what do we do now?
Well, Commander Radnor's sending some security guards.
A lot of good they'll do against an Ice Warrior.
Solar energy. When we were on the moon, Phipps made a trap.
Solar energy. Reflectors, of course! Well, we ought to be able to rig something up here.
Aye, well, you'd better be quick about it. That shield thing won't hold much longer.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A security team is making its way to the Bureau, clearing its path with water sprays. The Warrior has made a scorch mark on the door but that is all. Security reach the Bureau, open the main door and go inside. The Warrior meets them in a corridor and kills the lead two men while the others go down another corridor. The Doctor has been busy with wires, bulbs and two reflectors. Jamie is getting the last of the foam off the Doctor's jacket.

Dialogue.Line: Is this the sort of thing that Phipps rigged up, Zoe?
Well, sort of. It's not quite the same. His was bigger.
I think you'll find that this will be better for

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They hear gunfire outside.

Dialogue.Line: They're still shooting out there. They don't stand a chance, though.
Are you nearly ready, Doctor?
Yes, yes. Open the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds a reflector in each hand.

Dialogue.Line: Are you sure that thing works, now?
The only way to find out is to try, Jamie. Now open the door.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie opens the door.

Dialogue.Line: It's gone.
Must be chasing after those guards.
Another moment and we could have destroyed him. There's some more HD cable there.
Eh?
You reel it out and I'll make the connections.
What, this?
Yes, yes, that's it, Jamie. Hurry up.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Security are trying to lure the Warrior out of the Bureau.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe, stand by to throw the switch. Jamie, play out the cable.
Right.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor heads off down the corridors with his infra red devices, and finally encounters the Warrior.

Dialogue.Line: Now, Zoe!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Zoe switches on and the Ice Warrior melts.

Dialogue.Line: All right, Zoe!
No information yet available from Weather Control Bureau.
Oh, no. I'd better get over there. DOCTOR [on monitor]: T-Mat control? Commander Radnor? Ah.
Doctor! DOCTOR [on monitor]: This is the Doctor.

Doctor, are you all right? What's happening over there? DOCTOR [on monitor]: Yes, well, we've had quite a battle here, but things are all right now. There was a warrior here, but we've dealt with him.
Excellent! Is there much damage? DOCTOR [on monitor]: Well, yes, I'm afraid so. I'm going to see how much now. How are you getting along with the signal in the satellite?
Professor Eldred and Miss Kelly are coping with it now. DOCTOR [on monitor]: Good. I'll be back as soon as I can.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: How's it going?
We're ready to test.
Play back recording of homing beam.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The computer obeys.

Dialogue.Line: Now, that's the Ice-Warriors' homing beam. Let's see if I can produce that exactly.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: But it's too fast and high pitched. She adjusts it with a screwdriver.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, can't you get any closer than that?
I shall, don't worry!
That's it.
I'll lock it to that frequency.
Just one thing, Miss Kelly. Now that you've perfected this thing, how do you propose getting it to the launching pad without T-Mat?
It just so happens I found a petrol car in a motor museum.
Really? What make?
I've no idea, but it's got four wheels and it goes. Get this to the vehicle immediately.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A technician takes the homing beam away.

Dialogue.Line: Will a car be able to get through the foam?
Yes. I've arranged for a route to be cleared by hosing the foam.
Good, good.
But the only way we'll ever get rid of it permanently is by rain. Lots of rain!
It's hopeless, Doctor. You'll never get that thing going again.
I'm not so sure, Jamie. After all, it's only the controls that are damaged. The workings are all right. If we can bypass the controls. Have you got your knife on you?
Eh? Aye.
Lend it me, will you?
Be careful with this.
That's it, thank you.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor uses the sgian dubh to get inside the workings of the weather control unit.

Dialogue.Line: There we are. Now, what have we got here? Oh, yes. Yes, yes, yes. Yes, well, it's just a question of sorting this lot out, that's all.
You should not have killed him. Who will operate T-Mat?
I have studied the controls. MARSHALL [on monitor]: What if the apparatus breaks down?
I shall send warriors to Earth to bring back technicians. MARSHALL [on monitor]: Soon all humans on Earth will be extinct.
It will take time for the fungus to remove the oxygen from their atmosphere. MARSHALL [on monitor]: You must use that time to obtain another human, and do not kill him.
No, Grand Marshal. MARSHALL [on monitor]: You will be prepared to activate the homing beam on our signal?
All is prepared, Grand Marshal.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: I shall return to our ship to finalise invasion plans.

Right, now then, Zoe, let's see what happens when we try to connect these two together. (they spark.) No, I don't think so, somehow. What about these two? (no sparks so he twists the ends together) Ah, that's better. I think I've succeeded in re-establishing one of these rain circuits, Jamie.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie is up on a cat walk looking out of the window.

Dialogue.Line: It's not raining yet.
Oh, Jamie. Weather control is a very difficult technology. You can't expect immediate results.
Are you sure you're getting it right, Doctor?
Well, I hope so, Zoe. Just have to hope for the best, that's all. I must get on because there's another little job that I want to do.
Have you not got enough to do already?
What else is there?
Well, I want to make some alterations to my solar energy device.
Lift off in five seconds from now. Five. Four. Three. Two. One. Zero.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The rocket lifts off. The Doctor with his infra-red lamps, Zoe and Jamie enter.

Dialogue.Line: With any luck, we should have some nice heavy rain before long. Ah, there we are.
Yes, the satellite.
Isn't that a beautiful sight?
We finished and installed the homing device. It's working perfectly.
Well done.
Doctor? DOCTOR: Yes, Miss Kelly?
I know we're sending up a false signal, but aren't some of the Martian ships bound to follow the right one?
There isn't going to be a right one. There's only going to be ours, the wrong one, and that's going to lead the entire Martian fleet into an orbit around the sun.
What about Slaar's signal?
Oh, obviously that has to be stopped.
But how?
Well, as soon as the satellite is up, I shall T-Mat myself to the moon and destroy their homing device.
They'll kill you on sight.
Oh, I don't think so. I've rigged up a rather interesting little device here.
What's it for?
Well, it's a development of the solar energy device that you so successfully used on the moon, only I've succeeded in rendering it portable. I've got a solar battery.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The satellite has been deployed and is transmitting.

Dialogue.Line: Well, there it is. It's in orbit. We're now picking up the alien's homing signal from the moon. DOCTOR: Well, that means that their invasion fleet is getting closer. There's not time to be lost. Now, are you quite clear? As soon as I have succeeded in destroying their signal you must activate our signal in the satellite.
Oh, we'll be ready.
Right, then I'll be off.
Oh Doctor?
Yes? What is it, Zoe?
You will be careful, won't you?
Don't worry, Zoe, I will. Are you ready, Miss Kelly?
But Doctor, our control of T-Mat hasn't been tested.
Then now's the time to test it.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: It works. The only Warrior there has its back to the T-Mat cubicle. The Doctor sneaks out of the cubicle, the Warrior turns and the Doctor uses the solar projectors on it. The Doctor puts down his device and starts fiddling with the Slaar's communication device. Another Warrior enters with Slaar. The Doctor surrenders.

Dialogue.Line: No.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Warrior lowers its weapon.

Dialogue.Line: You, over there. I ordered you to be destroyed!
Well, you weren't very successful, were you.
Destroy that weapon.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The warrior fires.

Dialogue.Line: What is your purpose in coming here?
Well, you don't expect me to tell you that, do you?
The directional beam is still operative.
Yes. I'm afraid you were a little too quick for me.
Are you capable of operating the T-Mat mechanism?
Oh no, I don't think I could

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Slaar gestures the Warrior to shoot the Doctor.

Dialogue.Line: Well, well yes, perhaps I could get the hang of it.
As long as you can be useful to us, you can live. But this time there will be no escape. You will familiarise yourself with the T-Mat controls.
Oh, thank you very much.
You will not touch the controls until I give the order.
It's operating perfectly.
Good!
Shouldn't we have waited until the Doctor got back?
The moon signal has disappeared, hasn't it?
It may be purely atmospheric. For all we know they're still transmitting as strong as ever.
The moon signal was strong enough before the Doctor left. He must have succeeded.
Then why hasn't he come back?
We are receiving your homing signal clearly. Soon we shall enter the gravitational field of the moon.
All is prepared, Grand Marshal. I have obtained the services of another human. He will T-Mat our warriors to Earth. MARSHALL [on monitor]: Good. I shall resume transmission when landing is imminent.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: When our warriors arrive, you will transmit them to Earth under my direction.
Yes, but they haven't arrived yet, have they. Something still might go wrong, you know.
Nothing can go wrong now.
There's many a slip 'twixt the cup and the lip.
If anything does go wrong, you will be the first to die.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The invasion fleet is on radar.

Dialogue.Line: Scan closer!
If they are going to divert, if should happen any moment now.
Look, they're changing course.
I think you're right.
Yes, they're all following the satellite signal.
Then the Doctor must have succeeded. He must have turned off the Martian signal.
Well, what's happening up there, then? Why hasn't he come back?
Don't worry, Jamie. A squad of security guards armed with flamethrowers are on their way here now, and as soon as they get here we'll T-Mat them to the moon.
Oh, they'll be too late.
You'll just have to be patient!
Och, I'm sick of being patient!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie takes Zoe aside and whispers.

Dialogue.Line: Zoe. That T-Mat thing. Do you know how it works?
I think so. Why?
Could you T-Mat me back to the moon?
Oh, now Jamie, surely
Look, either the Doctor's all right, in which case we've no need to worry, or he's in danger and he needs my help.
Slaar! We are passing between Earth and moon! The signal has not led us into the moon's gravitational field!
Have you lost my signal? MARSHALL [on monitor]: Your signal is being received clearly, but we are off course.
Are you sure your calculations are correct? MARSHALL [on monitor]: Our calculations have been checked. You have sent us into an orbit close to the sun!

Use your retro-active rockets to change course! MARSHALL [on monitor]: It is too late. We have insufficient fuel for manoeuvre. You have failed us, Slaar! We shall all die! We are being drawn into the orbit of the sun!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Transmission ends.

Dialogue.Line: This is impossible!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Slaar checks the communications device.

Dialogue.Line: The signal. There is no power. You did this.
Yes. That signal has been going no further than this control room.
But they were receiving my signal.
Not your signal. Ours.
You sent a signal from Earth?
We sent up a satellite. That signal has sent your fleet into a false orbit.
The heat of the sun will kill them! You have destroyed our entire fleet!
You tried to destroy an entire world.
Earth will still die. The fungus will take the oxygen from your atmosphere.
No, I'm afraid that you've failed there too. We can destroy the fungus.
Kill him!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: A voice calls out from the T-Mat cubicle.

Dialogue.Line: Doctor!
Jamie, look out!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor leaps over the T-Mat control desk and tackles the Warrior. He diverts its aim so that Slaar dies instead of Jamie. Jamie runs across the room and leaps on the Warrior.

Dialogue.Line: Creag an tuire!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor holds up his solar energy power leads.

Dialogue.Line: Jamie, a live terminal!

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Jamie and the Doctor each press the leads into the Warrior's body. There is a bright flash and the Warrior collapses.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, well done, Jamie! Oh, goodness me! Jamie, thank you very much. Now then, we must T-Mat ourselves back to Earth.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: Where a heavy thunderstorm is washing away the foam.

Dialogue.Line: Wide spread rainfall throughout the country. Some flooding but none serious. Fungus rapidly disappearing. Weather Control Bureau coming back into operation. World food shortages partially relieved now T-Mat becoming operational again. Message to Commander Radnor from the Security Council of the United Nations. Congratulations.
All right, discontinue report.
So you really did know what you were doing at the Weather Control Bureau.
But, Zoe, of course I did!
Aye, well, it took long enough to work, eh?
Well, the rain seems to have disposed of the fungus well enough. Now the next thing to do is to get T-Mat fully operational again.
Yes, when moon relay's repaired we must check over the equipment and build in safeguards. From now on T-Mat must be entirely controlled from Earth.
Oh, surely you've learned not to put all of your eggs in one basket in future?
T-Mat in itself is perfectly effective.
You need a secondary transportation system. A fleet of rockets on permanent standby.
Yes, but Professor Eldred, we
There's no need to go to those lengths.
It's a question of common sense. I'm sure the Doctor will agree with me. Doctor.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor, Jamie and Zoe are not there.

Dialogue.Line: Did you have to make it rain as hard as all that?
Oh, Jamie, sometimes I think you're never satisfied.
What did you rush us back here for?
Well, you know, questions, explanations. It's very difficult. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: The Doctor enters the Tardis.

Dialogue.Line: Oh, where are going now?
Oh, it's no good asking him. He's no more idea than the man in the moon.
I heard that, Jamie. Come on.

Dialogue.Stage Direction: They all get into the Tardis, and it dematerialises.
